dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wall stretches in both directions as far as the eye c see. Barbed wire, armed sentries and guard dogs. This is dividing line. NAPOLEON SOLO crosses no-man’s land, past a sign which re ‘You are now entering East Germany.’ He’s in his 40's, po and confident, with a ready smile. He shows his passport an East German FRONTIER GUARD, addressing him in perfect German. The Guard gestures for him to open his suitcase. Packed a the top are samples of women’s underwear. Solo offers a sample to the Guard, who has a quick look o his shoulder, takes a pair of tights and then hurriedly closes the case, waving Solo through. As Solo leaves the checkpoint, a train is heading towards border as if to cross it, but as it reaches the Berlin Wa the track suddenly curves so that the train remains in th East, running parallel with the Wall. Clearly, a modifica made when the Wall was built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Solo walks along we see that he’s being followed. He's aware of it too. Solo enters a bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo orders a beer. As he drinks, he glances out of the window at the East German SECRET POLICEMAN who is followi him. Next to him, a prim-looking, middle-aged WOMAN finishes h coffee, dabs her lips with the napkin, and leaves. Solo unfolds the lipstick stained napkin. On it is an address, and a message, ‘YOU HAVE COMPETITION.’ Solo puts the napkin in his pocket and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo easily loses his tail. He heads to the address on the napkin. Outside is a car, gets in. INT. CAR — DAY The driver, ERNST, is a jovial looking fellow with an air gypsy about him. He flashes a gold-toothed smile at Solo.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: If I was a rich man, la la la la.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You're about to be. Here’s your scotch. Solo fetches a bottle of single malt out of his case.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: Glendronach 33. How did you find this?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You owe me. That was harder to get through than a pair of jeans.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: The jeans as well?? You’re the messiah. Solo produces the jeans.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: And you’re greedy, Ernst, but I like you anyway. Now here is an address, and we need to move, the Russians are onto my target. Ernst looks genuinely excited and starts to unbuckle his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing Ernst?

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: I can't wait... He continues his mission. Solo rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You even got the right size, and I am a little heavier than I used to be.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I predicted that. Did you get me a gun? Ernst pulls his coat off the back seat, only to reveal a large machine gun. SOLO (CONT’D) It’s a machine gun, Ernst. I asked for something discreet.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: I am sorry, but it’s the best I could do. The Stasi watch everything. Since the Russians took over, it’s almost impossible to make a dishonest living. Not like when you were in business. Don’t you miss the old black-market days? This hits a nerve with Solo.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: What? The hunger, the cold, the filth? Not really, can we go now? I’m in something of a rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernst points out a dodgy looking automotive repair shop u the arches of the busy railway track.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: It’s a chop shop, I used this place for years, but since things have tightened up, there’s not a lot of business here anymore. You want me to wait here?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Yeah, pick me up on the corner, and Ernst, we need to get the girl over the Wall tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ERNST
dialogues.text: It’s all arranged boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are covered with motor-racing posters and photographs of famous drivers. Solo approaches a mechanic who is working under a car, we just see a pair of feet.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: (in German) I’m looking for Frau Teller. The mechanic rolls out from under the car. Meet GABY TELL a 28 year-old knockout in a boiler suit.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: (in German) I'm a little backed up, I won’t be able to get to your car until next week. Gaby affects a hard edge but her clothing, ruffled hair a the oil-smudge on her cheek only serve to accentuate her vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (in German) My name is Napoleon Solo. I’m here about your father Frau Teller. Gaby tenses. Solo smiles reassuringly. SOLO (CONT’D) We need your help.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: (in English) American? Solo nods.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven't seen my father since I was ten years old.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I imagine you're aware of what your father did during the war?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: He was the senior scientist in the Nazi rocket program. Is there anything else to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, he came to work for the U.S. at Los Alamos. Five years ago, he disappeared without a trace. We've been looking for him ever since, but this is the first sign we've had of him. This picture was taken a week ago by one of our agents in Egypt. Solo shows Gaby a black-and-white photograph of half a do men seated at a conference table. Three are wearing high level military uniforms. Solo points to one man who is standing, gesticulating wit his arms as if to make a point. He’s an older professoria type.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: That’s him... She can’t hide the emotion in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It appears your father is in the process of making a deal to sella nuclear bomb to the Egyptians. That’s not great news for Israel, which isn’t good news for the rest of us. Nasty business nuclear war.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not proud of what my father has done, but I told you, I haven’t seen or heard from him in eighteen years.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: We believe he’s working for this man. He points to a man seated next to the Professor. He’s dre in an expensive linen suit but his face is mostly covered the Professor’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can’t help you. She disappears back under the car. Solo pulls her back ou again.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: But I bet you know someone who can. An old friend, a relative?  Gaby thinks about it, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can't...

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: If you'll agree to help us, I can have you on the other side of the Wall tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You do understand that I could be tortured and imprisoned just for listening to you?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I’m offering you a new life. Freedom from all of that.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: How do I know you are who you say you are? How do I know that anything you’ve told me is true? He looks her directly in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I know this is sudden. I wish there was more time. But that’s how urgent the situation is. I will protect you and I will get you over that wall. I just need you to...

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Trust you?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Trust me. And she almost does. Almost but...

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Why? Because you’re handsome and have a nice smile?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Shall I make this easier? He reveals the machine gun under his jacket. SOLO (CONT’D) You're now my prisoner, you don’t have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does make it easier.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I have a driver waiting for us outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo heads out the door and slows abruptly. He notices th Ernst’s car is not quite in the same place, and it’s hard see Ernst. He’s at a strange angle, Solo doesn’t like thi he drops down quickly as a bullet whistles past his ear. He rolls back into the shop.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: (afraid) What’s going on? Who just shot at us?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I need the keys to that thing.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: The Russians are after your father too. It’s us or them. Like I said, you don’t have a choice. Beat, as her mind clearly shifts.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I’m the only person who drives this car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shooter moves closer to get a better angle on the entrance to the garage. Meet ILYA KURYAKIN, Russian, he’s his early 30’s and radiates a rare combination of physica power and intelligence. However in contrast, his choice of clothing is distinctly odd. He wears a suit, but it’s a conspicuously bold color and shirt and tie have striking patterns which are completely mismatched. On anyone else, this get-up would look clowni but Kuryakin manages to make it look cool. As he’s crossing the street, Gaby’s car roars out. Kuryak snaps his gun up to take aim, but instead of turning down street, Gaby drives up on the sidewalk to be shielded by parked vehicles. Kuryakin lowers his gun, calmly walks back to his car, cl in, and roars after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaby’s car screeches around the corner, scattering pedestrians. Other cars are forced to swerve out of the w In the car, Gaby is clearly in her element. Her confidenc returns as she focuses on driving which she does with ext ordinary skill. Kuryakin follows, relentless.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Gaby slams on the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: This guy isn’t going to give up.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I am aware of that, but what are you doing? She slams the car into reverse and tightens her safety be

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Hold on tight. This car is tougher than it looks. She hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KURYAKIN’S CAR - DAY He rounds the corner to find Gaby looking over her should reversing straight at him at forty miles an hour. Kuryaki has no time to dodge.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. EAST BERLIN STREETS —- DAY CRASH. There is an enormous smash as both cars come to a halt. However, Gaby’s car is relatively undamaged. She te away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Gaby turns to a shaken Solo.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Where did you learn to drive like this?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What’s the point in fixing cars if you can’t drive them?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. EAST BERLIN STREETS —- DAY Kuryakin coolly climbs out of the wreckage of his car, an surveys all the other cars that have stopped to look at t incident. He eventually sees one at the back, it looks fa He walks up to the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (in German) I saw the whole thing, that woman's a lunatic! Kuryakin waves his gun at him with a gesture that says “t is my car now” and the journey continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY She continues to drive fast, avoiding traffic, but eventu she finds herself behind a rubbish truck, picking up tras Another car is close behind her, she’s stuck. She calmly looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: We can’t stay here.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Really? You’re very observant. She glances at a parallel road a block over, searching fo another way out. Suddenly, a car tears down the parallel road. We only see it for a flash, but we know it’s Kuryak Solo and Gaby look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He couldn’t have seen us? Pause. We hear a screech of tires.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Shall we get out of here? Kuryakin’s car tears back and stops. How could he possibl have seen them? Within a second, he is firing shots from pistol just inches away from their target. Gaby doesn’t hang around. Again she puts the car in rever forcing the car behind her back. This gives her enough ro to mount the curb, knocking the TRASH COLLECTORS out of t way. She’s off again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KURYAKIN’S CAR - DAY Kuryakin steers with one hand, and shoots with the other. He’s calmer than a coma.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo shoots back. Gaby downshifts.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: That man can drive. Can’t you shoot better than that?  11.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You concentrate on the road. She makes a hard left into an alley. Solo is thrown to one side and drops his gun on the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuryakin overshoots.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo picks up his gun.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Better? Suddenly, her expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no! Up ahead is a sharp drop as a steep stone pedestrian staircase leads down to the road below. Solo looks behind them. Kuryakin is catching up again. Si are approaching behind him. Gaby is slowing down. Solo stays cool.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: We can make it. Gaby is shaking her head. Solo starts to climb into the b seat.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: We need more weight in the back.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can't...  12.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You can. You don’t, we’re both dead... Trust me... Now put your foot down. Gaby looks at him, hits the gas, and they’re airborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazingly, the car lands on the steps, the back flies up, it doesn't flip. Instead, it carries on down the steps, reaching the bottom with a crunch. Kuryakin stops his car at the top of the steps. He climbs of his car and watches them speed away. INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. You alright?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: That’s a stupid question.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Shall I drive now?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You’re okay, pal. Just stay where you are. More sirens. Flashing lights in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: In there. He points to a multi-story parking structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaby parks her car. INT. CAR — DAY Solo and Gaby sit, tensely listening to the sirens go by. Gradually, the sound fades into the distance.  13.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Still going over the Wall tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Follow me. He climbs out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Solo and Gaby head for the exit, a car turns into the structure. Solo pulls Gaby down behind a car. As the vehicle passes, they see that it’s Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Who is this guy? He pulls her through the back-door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he and Gaby hurry down the alleyway, Solo looks back t see Kuryakin, looking down at him from the second floor o the parking structure. Solo pulls Gaby around the corner and breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo and Gaby run. And run. And run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by industrial warehouses. Solo and Gaby crouch hidden in the shadows of one of the warehouses. They are of breath and Gaby looks spent.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: We haven’t lost him, have we? Solo puts a finger to his lips. A long beat. Sure enough, Kuryakin appears between the buildings, coming towards th A distant rumble grows louder. A train trundles along the tracks moving between them and Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Come on.  14. He pulls Gaby up, and they run towards the train. Solo manages to open one of the doors and push Gaby in. On the other side, Kuryakin scans the night as the end of train passes gradually, revealing the warehouses that wer hidden behind it. It appears that Kuryakin is going to let the train pass. the last minute, he runs to catch up with the final carri and jumps onboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo has been watching from the window. He pulls his head

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Did he get on?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Let’s move.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: This is your idea of going over the Wall? He leads her towards the front of the train. As they head along the passageway, the CONDUCTOR exits a compartment.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: (in German) Tickets please. He looks slightly suspicious at their dishevelled state.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Two tickets for the Center please. He pays the Conductor, who takes forever to give them cha As they continue down the passageway, Kuryakin appears at other end. They hurry down the train. Finally, they reach the hallway outside the driver's compartment. They can go no further. Solo opens the exterior door, but the train is travelling fast to jump off. He looks ahead and sees the Berlin Wall approaching.  15. SOLO (CONT’D) The train has to slow down to make the turn when it reaches the Wall. That's when we jump. Sirens and flashing lights. Solo looks out again. There a now two cop cars driving alongside the train. Here comes Kuryakin. Solo ducks around the corner, just a volley of silenced machine gun fire thuds into the wall n to his head. Gaby is crouched down, covering her head, body shaking.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: (yells down the corridor) You have no place to go, Mr. Solo. Give yourself up. There’s no reason for the girl to die.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (to himself) He knows my name???? Solo knows he’s right unless... He tries the Driver’s door. Locked. Solo shoots the lock, barges the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo sticks his gun in the DRIVER'S face. He’s a big, str fellow.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: (in German) Faster.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: We won’t make the turn. The train will crash into... He gestures to the approaching Berlin Wall.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Faster. The Driver doesn’t move, but his eyes give him away, flic to the accelerator handle.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Thank you.  16. Solo jams the accelerator forward. At that moment, the Dr grabs for the gun. They grapple as the Wall approaches. Suddenly, Kuryakin is in the cabin, his gun in Solo’s fac He squeezes the trigger as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train jumps the tracks and smashes through the Wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo, Kuryakin, and the Driver are tossed around as the f of the train rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a massive hole in the Wall. More than half the length of the train has gone through it, and is now in th West. The front carriage is on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo swims back into consciousness. The Driver lies groan next to him. Solo crawls into the passageway. He sees the girl, and he a groan, she’s semi-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Gaby?!...Can you hear me? Her eyes open. SOLO (CONT’D) You're going to be alright. You’re safe now. We hear the sound of sirens as West German POLICE turn up Kuryakin is stuck in the wreckage, and can’t free himself easily, he can see his targets disappearing as he attempt pull himself out.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo watches as a DOCTOR examines Gaby. She winces as he touches her bruised ribs.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (to himself) Welcome to freedom. There’s a knock on the door and SANDERS enters. He’s an effete little man with an air of great cunning and intelligence about him. He’s also Solo’s boss.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well done Solo. Solo stares at him for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Why don’t we step outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders puts the kettle on.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, it appears the Russians are as anxious as we are to find Professor Teller.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: What is your secret? (beat) You know there’s no one in the history of the Agency with a higher success rate when it comes to recruiting and running female assets. You’re a bit of a legend. A long pause. Solo stares at Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You heard what I said.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You need a break.  18.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: No, I have had enough. Twelve years of playing your little games. I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You seem to be forgetting something... You’re on thin ice Solo, and there are things, unpleasant things, lurking under it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Threatening me with a prison cell has lost its traction Sanders. Put me away, it’s better for everyone's health.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together Solo. Solo suddenly grabs him by the throat and pins him agains the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: This won’t mean much to you, but she trusted me.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Look Solo, she’s going to be okay. There's a beat, Solo releases his grip.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tell you what, let’s meet again tomorrow, we’ll talk about it sensibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EGYPTIAN OFFICER is running outside the barracks, he l fit and has an expression like he means it. We become awa of a man running up behind him. This is ALEXANDER SKORPIO he’s dressed to run.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Colonel. I heard you were an early bird. The Egyptian acknowledges him, but continues running.  19.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: I like the sand before the sun beats it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I hope I am not bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Not in the least, you and the Professor have done Egypt a great service... But I thought you had left already, Mr... “Smith.”

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I’m back for the day. A couple of loose ends I needed to tie up. By way, my name is Alex...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: No. Please. Let’s stick to protocol.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m confident you can be trusted Colonel. I’m Alexander Skorpios.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Good to meet you, Mr. Skorpios.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You're quite a legend in the camp, Colonel, winner of the army triathlon six years in a row. (beat) Do you mind if I train with you today? I am an amateur athlete myself and this will be my last opportunity, since our business is concluded.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: You’re welcome to, but I warn you, this is not a short work out.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Two hours every morning. A twelve mile run, followed by a two mile swim, and a cool down in the gym. Your routine is famous. I’1l drop out as soon as you pull away.  20.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Very good then.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: An hour later. Alexander has clearly impressed the Colone COLONEL (CONT’D) You are doing very well, Mr. Skorpios.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I am inspired by my company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the Colonel is a tad concerned by the determination and ability of this man. They have reached sea.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: So, the sea. I go round the buoy, then back again.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I am ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later. Alexander is clearly in front and showing signs of fatigue, the Colonel on the other hand is now tr to keep up... EXT. EGYPTIAN BEACH —- MORNING Alexander is waiting on the beach... jogging on the spot. Colonel pulls himself out of the water, he’s desperately trying to not look knackered.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Where did you learn to swim like that?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My father taught me that true physical strength lies not in the body, but in the mind. If you chew bitter for long enough, eventually it turns sweet. The gym?  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander is on the bench with a bar over him...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Could you spot me? Alexander thumps out ten reps of a very heavy weight.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: That weight is too much.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It’s all in your mind, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The Colonel is on the bench, under a weight that he has t struggle with. Alexander stands over him, almost mockingl

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Push push, that’s the spirit Colonel, now we're getting somewhere. Let’s see how strong you really are. At which point, Alexander releases the weight and the Col takes the strain.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's it. Now tell me, how long have you been a spy? The Colonel is about to explode with the weight that’s ov him.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Take the weight off me. I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You're just not trying hard enough. Who are you working for, the Americans, or the Russians? The Colonel can’t take the weight for much longer.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Please...!  22.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Tell me what I want to know, and I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: The Americans... and the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Thank you Colonel. Alexander reaches down and takes hold of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You and your government have no idea who you're dealing with Colonel. With almost superhuman strength, he raises the bar before slams it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful sunny day. Solo is walking with Sanders through public gardens.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: How’s the girl? Is she going to be helpful? He walks into a public restroom, gesturing that Solo shou follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanders checks the cubicles.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I think so...

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You’1l have to do better than that.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: There’s an old friend and colleague of her father’s, a Rudolph Von Trulsch, endearingly known as “Uncle Rudi.” Lives in Greece, works for a big shipping company. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's sure if anybody will be in touch with her father, he’s the man. Sanders is relieving himself.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Rudi Von Trulsch. I think I have a file on him somewhere. Name of the shipping company?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Triton.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Even more interesting, rumor has it they smuggled Nazi gold to South America after the war. Can she be trusted?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: That’s your department now sir, I got you the girl and I got you a name. Now I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: No Solo, you'll be done when I tell you you're done.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I don’t think you understand. I am over it, for about a thousand reasons, not least of which, I am losing whatever advantage I had over these people. That lunatic Russian android they put on me yesterday isn’t like men I have come up against before. He was a relentless Olympian. That was the closest I have come to termination in the last ten years. It wasn’t me that saved me, it was a banana skin here and a rabbit foot there. In other words, luck. You want to send me back to the cell, send me. I’11 go. But I am done here. A MAN wearing a hat enters, shutting Sanders up. Solo looks over his shoulder as the Man raises his head, Kuryakin. They both look as surprised as the other about unlikely meeting.  24. Without another word, they spring into action. They attem to draw their guns, but there isn’t enough space to use t A serious amount of hand-to-hand combat takes place, destroying the lavatory. It ends with Kuryakin putting a choke hold around Solo’s neck. Solo looks up for help from Sanders, he doesn’t have much time. His boss calmly washes his hands as he gasps his la breath. Solo spots an owl-like man entering the room. This is Kuryakin’s boss, OLEG. He has the eccentric appearance of chess grandmaster. He barks an order at Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: Let him go Ilya. You don’t want to kill your partner on the first day. Kuryakin’s hold gradually relaxes, both men look shocked this information. Solo looks up at his boss, who throws a the paper towel.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: That's what I was about to explain Solo, but as usual you jumped the gun. We were going to meet them in the cafe outside. Nature’s needs clearly got the better of their agent as he did of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oleg sips a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: We don’t know yet who is behind this but we both agree, not that Sanders and I have ever talked before... He and Sanders chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-that it’s unacceptable to both our nations to have a third party manufacturing and selling nuclear weapons to the highest bidder. Sanders nods.  25.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Our mutual interests dictate that we should work together. Unofficially and off-the-books, of course, if the politicians knew about this...

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (to Sanders) You're forgetting something.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Excuse us for a second. Solo come with me. Sanders stands and Solo follows.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am not asking you to find the President's missing sticky book, it’s nuclear war we're talking about!... If that’s not enough, and prison isn’t, then how about secret account number 583937994? Your retirement policy. A tidy little sum from your noir racketeering days... That account is now frozen, and I am the only man who can make it thaw, but first, you’re going to go to work.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: That man sitting there is the enemy! He killed your top agent in East Berlin not twenty-four hours ago, and spent the majority of yesterday trying very hard to kill me...

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Well, you’1l be in safe hands then. You yourself reported on how capable he was. There is no choice in this Solo. Finish the job and then, and only then, are you done. Now, we have twenty-four hours to get ready then you head to Greece with the Russian and the girl, as a team. Solo, looks over to Kuryakin. They just stare at each oth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights off, a Super 8 film fills us in: Images of a child soldier getting a medal. A young man swimming in the Olympics. Another image pops up of him firing a gun at a target with deadly accuracy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Kuryakin’s father was killed by the Nazis at the siege of Leningrad. The day he got the news, our boy joined the army. He was fourteen. Killed so many Germans he was given the nickname “The Leningrad Plague.” The KGB recruited him after the war and spent years refining him. His one flaw appears to be his temper. But make no mistake, he’s their top agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oleg clicks his finger and the lights are off, and Oleg w in front of the film projected onto a wall. Now it’s Solo turn.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG, (SUBTITLE)
dialogues.text: Solo was a sergeant in the Marines during the war. He was awarded the Military Cross for bravery. He was stationed in Berlin after the war, where he became involved in multiple criminal activities, mostly dealing in black-market goods. He speaks many languages, and he’s highly cultured for all the wrong reasons. He has a a broad knowledge of art, wine, antiques, only in order to know it’s black market value. He was facing a fifteen year prison sentence for his crimes, but the CIA recognized his talent and offered to withhold his sentence, as long as he worked for them. Since then, he has been involved in some of their most important and dangerous clandestine operations. He has consistently bested our top operatives. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s not predictable. He’s not a product of the system. Kuryakin nods. Sanders paces in front of Solo.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: Your main mission is to prevent the delivery of the bomb. That is the first priority. However, you have a second obligation. Professor Teller’s research represents the next generation of nuclear weapons technology. It’s way ahead of anything we or the Russians have currently, and clearly he’s succeeded in putting it into practice. That research will be on a disk. We must have that disk and above all else, it must not fall into the hands of the Russians. Oleg lies on a sofa while Kuryakin paces.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: ...it is essential that we get it and not the Americans. Once you have completed your main mission... Sanders stops pacing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: You are to use any means... Oleg gets off the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: OLEG
dialogues.text: ..-mecessary to secure it. Do I make... Sanders stares at Solo. 27.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERS
dialogues.text: ..-myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaby sits opposite Solo, who passes her a cup of tea. She looking much better.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I kept my end of the deal, and I almost died for it. And now you want me to come to Greece?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Look we don’t have much time, and I need access to Uncle Rudi. If anybody knows where your father is, it’s him, and if there’s one person he’ll tell, it’s you.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can’t do this. I don’t know this world, you’re asking me to be something I am not.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Trust me. All I need you to be is yourself. I’11l guide you through it, this is what I do. Look at it as a holiday. You can see the sights, get a tan. And I promise there'll be no danger. She's melting.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Promise. The chemistry between them is undeniable, but Solo’s all business. SOLO (CONT’D) Now, you need some clothes. Let’s go shopping.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice mid-range place that sells sensible clothes. Solo watches as Gaby looks at dresses. He spots an elegant black dress.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: This one isn’t bad. He shows Gaby the dress. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Black is for funerals. She turns to look at another dress. A troubled look passe over Solo’s face. He’s all too aware that Gaby’s wellbein again his responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So Russia and America have become friends over this issue have they?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Well, friends might be an overstatement... But as coincidence would have it, you do already know the man we have to partner with.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Know him? How can I know him? At which point, Solo spots Kuryakin. As usual, he’s dress in an outlandishly colorful and mismatched get-up, which somehow manages to make cool.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (to Kuryakin) You're early.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: We're in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Wait just a second. Isn’t that the man...?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. I told you, you know him.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding.  30.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It’s going to be fine. Kuryakin smiles and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Ilya Kuryakin. You are quite a driver young lady, I like that ina woman.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I feel sick. Make it stop.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: That’s perfectly normal, you'll get used to the feeling. He sees the dress.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Did you pick this dress? Looking at Solo. KURYAKIN (CONT’D) There is no way my woman is wearing this dress.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What do you mean “my woman?” Solo, what does he mean?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I think you should leave this department to me, no offense but...

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: My fiancee would never wear this.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Fiancee? They ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Really, now you're a Russian fashion expert? And that suit is your qualification?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: So you’re an expert on what a Russian architect looks like, Cowboy?  31.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I’m not doing this. She storms out of the shop. Solo looks sarcastically at I

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Good work.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Your job was to prepare her.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Your job was to give me time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful evening. Gaby paces in front of a founta while Solo talks.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: He’s an architect designing a new resort for heroes of the Soviet Union by the Black Sea. The Minister has a weakness for classical architecture so he’s been sent to Greece to study it. He’s managed to get a visa for his fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: (in horror) Me?!

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It’s the perfect cover. Since Uncle Rudi lives in Athens, it’s only natural that you would pay hima visit to tell him the good news, and ask him about your father.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Now you want me to be an actress?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It’s easier than it seems, I’11l coach you through it. Gaby shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: This is insane.  32.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You can do it Gaby, I'll admit it’s a challenge, but I know you can handle it. She considers, but again she’s melting.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I’m doing this. What will you be doing while I’m playing the Russian bride?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I'll be playing an executive for American oil, on a business trip to check out Triton shipping, Rudi’s employer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROFESSOR UDO TELLER, Gaby’s father, stands alone on the rocks, staring out to sea. Looming over him on the cliffs above is a medieval castle Two men approach him from the direction of the fortress. is Alexander Skorpios. The other is another older gentlem very well dressed, with a mane of thick white hair. There an air of dissipation about him. Meet RUDOLPH VON TRULSCH “UNCLE RUDI.”

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Hello Udo. The Professor is startled from his reverie.

dialogues.speaker: UDO
dialogues.text: Rudi. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I asked him to come. Alexander clearly makes Udo nervous.

dialogues.speaker: UDO
dialogues.text: (to Uncle Rudi) What do you want me to say? I’ve served loyally for twenty-five years, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: No one is questioning your loyalty.  33.

dialogues.speaker: UDO
dialogues.text: It is one thing for the organization to have nuclear capability for the purposes of leverage or deterrent. It’s quite another for us to sell the bomb to other parties, who will use it to commit genocide.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The orders come directly from the Reichs-Marshall in Buenos Aires. It is not for you to question them.

dialogues.speaker: UDO
dialogues.text: (shouting) They didn’t build it! They’re not directly responsible!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It’s too late for second thoughts Professor. You must finish the job you started! (to Uncle Rudi) Talk to him. He turns and leaves. Rudi puts a calming hand around the Professor’s shoulders

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: I have some happy news, Udo. I’ve heard from Gaby. The blood drains from Udo's face. UNCLE RUDI (CONT’D) She's coming to Athens, with her new fiancee. Imagine our little Gabriella getting married. Perhaps it’s time for a reunion? Udo looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: UDO
dialogues.text: I don’t want her involved in this. Keep her away Rudi. Promise me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo walks onto the plane, stops for a second, and sees Kuryakin and Gaby sitting together in first class. She ha seen Solo, but Kuryakin has, and takes a sip of champagne  34. Solo takes a step in their direction when he is stopped b the STEWARDESS. She looks at his ticket...

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Sorry sir, your seat’s the other way...

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: You must do what I tell you to do, when I tell you to do it... It could save your life. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Good, now laugh... spontaneously, deeply, viscerally... Solo takes this in as the Stewardess points him towards t economy seats, filled with distinctly un-glamorous people Gaby laughs. Solo looks back at his new partner, who look over his shoulder before he whispers back in Gaby’s ear.. KURYAKIN (CONT’D) Good. Now, where did we first have dinner?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh, you’re just too funny, aren't you, Babushka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent palace of a building in the best part of to Solo exits a cab. A BELL-BOY hurries over to relieve him his luggage and escorts him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oozing luxury and old school grandeur. This is clearly th place where the Athenian jet-set meet.  35. As Solo approaches the check-in desk, he passes Kuryakin Gaby being escorted to the elevator. Solo waits as the guest ahead of him finishes checking in He’s a distinguished looking older man.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Enjoy your stay, Mr. Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: WAVERLY
dialogues.text: (English accent) Thank you, my good man. Solo smiles at the pretty DESK CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Holstein. Checking in.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Welcome to Athens, Mr. Holstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo sighs as he takes in the narrow single bed and the window which looks out to the wall of the adjacent buildi

dialogues.speaker: BELL-BOY
dialogues.text: Is there anything else I can help you with, Mr. Holstein? Solo tips the Bell-Boy who looks very pleased with the amount. The Bell-Boy leaves, the door shuts. Solo looks a his watch and goes to open the door. There is a MAN stand there with another case, he looks surreptitiously down th corridor, and then passes the case to Solo.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: You have an appointment with the owner of Triton shipping tomorrow morning. Details are in here. He hands Solo an envelope and disappears. Solo unpacks the case. He presses a secret latch revealin false bottom. Underneath is his spy gear: an automatic wi silencer, a couple of false passports, miniature camera, an assortment of electronic bugging and tracking devices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaby stands on the balcony admiring the view of the Acropolis.  36. There’s a knock at the door. Kuryakin replaces the false bottom in his very similar suitcase, concealing his own s gear, before letting Solo in. Gaby hands Solo an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Uncle Rudi has invited us for dinner this evening. Solo looks at the card.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Us... He points to himself and Gaby.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: That's fortuitous, Taverna Tony. I've heard it’s the best restaurant in Athens. I’1l be close by.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Take the evening off Cowboy. We won’t need you.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It wasn’t you I was thinking of, Kalinka. I'll be there anyway. A man has to eat and I like a sun- dried octopus. Kuryakin finishes knotting his tie, and puts on his jacke Once again, the clothes should be ridiculous, but Kuryaki somehow pulls it off. SOLO (CONT’D) Do you want me to lend you a tie? Kuryakin just laughs and stands next to Gaby.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: How do we look, John Wayne?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Like a beautiful wave clipper weighed down by a very heavy anchor.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to him angel, you look magnificent.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: No one can accuse you of cowardice, Stalin. Kuryakin takes a ring out of his pocket and slips it on Gaby’s engagement finger.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Now... like we’re lovers. He takes her hand and goes to kiss her on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Where do you think you’re going?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Practice angel, practice.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Practice on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outdoor restaurant on the most fashionable boulevard i Athens. The rich and the beautiful populate the streets a bars, drinking cocktails at the candlelit tables, or driv by in their open-topped Italian and British sports cars. A group of paparazzi are hanging out in front, photograph the guests as they come and go. Kuryakin and Gaby are seated at one of the best tables.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Uncle Rudi has been good to me. He paid for private tutors for years in Germany, so he likes to play at being my father sometimes. So, understand if he starts to grill you. Solo is seated at a table near the door. He’s listening t the conversation through a tiny earpiece. He eats his oct while reading a guide book. He has a camera around his ne He takes the occasional snapshot. Typical American touris A massive Mercedes pulls up. The CHAUFFEUR hurries to ope the door and out steps Uncle Rudi. Solo notices him nod almost imperceptibly to two THUGS standing on the far side of the road. He snaps a shot of and zooms his lens to reach the Thugs.  38.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Gabriella my darling! Age is being much kinder to you than it is to me. So rare that a facade so pure, reflects so accurately the goods it contains. He kisses her hand. Kuryakin rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You're doing it again Uncle, stop with your flattery.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Nonsense, I report the truth. I never thought I’d see you out of that country of darkness. The light of freedom treats you well. No disrespect to you young man, or should I call you Comrade? He turns to Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Whatever makes you happy sir.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: What will make me happy, is to know that my Gabriella will be marrying aman that’s worthy of her. And how long have you two lovebirds known each other?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Two years Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: You didn’t think to mention him. Were you ashamed? Kuryakin looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Why should she be?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: I appreciate that the equity of aristocratic blood is wasted on a communist, however, even a Russian peasant must recognize the incompatibility of mixing the blood of a race horse with that of a cart horse.  39. The Russian goes quiet as he tries to calculate the depth the insult that has been levelled at him.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You must forgive Rudi, Ilya dearest, he’s a terrible snob. And not to be taken to seriously. The Russian is speechless, his hands grip the side of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Tell me Ilya, did they get you to build the Wall before they put you behind it? You are shaped like a power lifter, not an architect! The Russian forces himself to speak.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I like to jog...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Does Gabriella ride on your back? You must jog a great deal to look like that, it’s a wonder you have any time for architecture. And where do you jog to? Or is it the kind of jogging that goes nowhere? Please tell me it’s not that, not the “old dog chasing its tail” routine. We can see the Russian has had enough.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: No, jogging’s the warmup to the “pulling the tongues out of old men who have forgotten what trouble it can get them into” routine. Pause, this could go either way. Solo, who’s heard everything, looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: A sense of humor and a muscled corsair’s daring, all wrapped up in a tie that can only be worn by a man permanently drunk on courage. I commend you on your choice Gaga, a rare find. Now let’s order.  40. Rudi gives a slight nod, and the Greek band strikes up a tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuryakin, Gaby, and Uncle Rudi are on their coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Uncle, I’ve been wondering about my father. I’d give anything to see him again. You're his greatest friend, I thought perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Your father is a fugitive, my dear. A hunted man. He’d be very foolish to be anywhere in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: But if there were any way to reach him? His only daughter is getting married after all. Rudi shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Gabriella, I feel for you as I would for my own child, but I’m afraid I can’t help you. He stands. UNCLE RUDI (CONT’D) And now, it’s getting late. I highly recommend that you take the short stroll back to your hotel. The Acropolis at night is something not to be missed, especially for an architect. Solo watches as they exit. Rudi points which way to walk before he is whisked away in the massive Mercedes. As Kuryakin and Gaby stroll up the boulevard, the two Thu from the beginning of the scene start to follow them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuryakin and Gaby turn the corner.  41.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you threatened to pull his tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have pulled it out, just stretched it a little. We used to do it in the early days, it takes quite a lot of technique.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: No you weren’t.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Okay, I wasn’t, but that doesn’t matter now. What does is that Rudi knows exactly where your father is.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure? They are interrupted by the sudden arrival of a moped, it Solo.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You're being followed.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I know, two of them. “Goose-step” Rudi sent them. I know what they’re doing here, but I don’t know what you're doing here. I told you I didn’t need your help.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Oh yes, you do. Now give me your gun, before it gets us all into trouble. You’ve clearly got a very short temper... threatening to pull his tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: It’s not very short.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Yes it is.  42.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It’‘ll happen around the next corner. It’s quiet and they’ve put the street lamp out. Remember, you're an architect, take it like a pussy. Now give me your gun. I don’t have time to argue. Kuryakin rolls his eyes and obliges.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Kuryakin reluctantly hands the gun over. Solo zooms off o the moped.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Act scared.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I don’t need to act. Here come the two Thugs. One pushes Kuryakin against the and jabs a knife against his throat. Kuryakin’s fingers twitch, but then his hand relaxes. The other grabs Gaby by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Money!

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes... Take whatever you want. We don’t want any trouble. Thug 1 rifles through Kuryakin’s pockets, takes his money The other does the same with Gaby’s purse. Then he pulls rings off her finger.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Watch.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Please, it was my father’s, it’s not worth anything. Thug 1 slaps him, hard.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Now!  43. Kuryakin grits his teeth. It’s taking all of his self con not to react as Thug 1 rips the watch off his wrist and pauses, he looks into Kuryakin’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your woman’s braver than you. He slaps him again. Kuryakin fakes fear... but he slightl betrays himself. He gets slapped again.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You have what you want, now please leave us!

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Nothing to say big man? Slap...

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Nothing? What’s all the muscles for? Another slap, then the two men run off. Solo steps out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Everyone okay? Kuryakin groans.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Enjoy the show? Solo hands him back his gun.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Good restraint. Your father’s watch. Nice touch.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: (annoyed) It wasn’t a touch, it was his watch.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I still don’t understand. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Your Uncle Rudi wanted to find out if Kalinka here really was an architect, and not some short-— tempered lunatic Russian spy.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I want my watch back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaby is talking on the telephone, watched by Solo and Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Right after we left you, Uncle Rudi. It was horrible... They beat poor Ilya... No he'll be okay, it’s just the shock, he felt so helpless and weak. She looks at Kuryakin with a slight smile, he doesn’t ret it. GABY (CONT’D) Yes, the hotel is sending a doctor. okay, good-night then. She hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s invited us to the racetrack tomorrow, to watch his employer's team practice.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: And I have an appointment to meet the same man tomorrow morning, early, to discuss oil tankers. INT. ALEXANDER SKORPIOS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Rudi hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: She'll be coming to the racetrack tomorrow.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Good. She’s exactly what we need to convince her father to finish the job. What do you think about the Russian?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: I am not sure.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well you need to be.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Leave it with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi drops Solo off outside, a brand new ultra-modern building at the entrance to one of the piers, TRITON SHIPPING. EXT. TRITON HEADQUARTERS —- COURTYARD - DAY A SECRETARY leads Solo through a beautifully landscaped garden filled with classical sculptures.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: This way, Mr. Holstein.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Impressive sculptures.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: We're proud to be the largest private restorers of antiquities in all of Greece. They continue past a converted warehouse with big glass walls, where there are twenty MARTIAL ARTS STUDENTS fight SECRETARY (CONT’D) And this is our Spartan Boxing Academy. It was founded by Mr. Skorpios’ father. Legend has it that the three hundred Spartans used this same fighting style to hold off ten thousand Persians at the battle of Thermopylae. Solo notices a very attractive young woman among them, sh appears to be a skillful fighter.  46. SECRETARY (CONT’D) This way please. They enter a modernist pavilion in the middle of the gard INT. ALEXANDER SKORPIOS’ OFFICE - DAY A huge room. Alexander Skorpios finishes issuing orders t underling. Solo looks at a series of family photographs on the wall. Pictures of: Alexander and Elena as children; their mothe beautiful older woman, and in pride of place, a picture o big brute of a man, ACHILLES SKORPIOS, standing in front fishing boat with his two young children.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Mr. Holstein?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Quite a set up you have here, Mr. Skorpios.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You liked our Spartan Boxing Academy? Great exercise and so much less boring than running or going to the gym. My father practiced it everyday and he lived to ninety- eight! You should try it sometime.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I’m not much of a fighter.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well, we could always have my sister give you a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I’m not sure whether to be flattered or offended.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Please sit down. Can I get you a coffee or anything?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Holstein, I’m surprised that we haven’t met before. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought I knew everyone at Texas Oil.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I’m freelance, so to speak Mr. Skorpios. My employers are not happy with their current shippers, and they are looking to make a change, but they don’t necessarily want to advertise their intentions by sending their own executives.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: So you’re not here to spy on us?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Well, if I am, I am not about to admit it to you sir. But I’m intrigued, why would the owner of a shipping company be worried about spies?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The biggest shipping company in the world, Mr. Holstein. We can move four billion tons of oil a year, which I trust will be enough to cover your needs. But our aerospace department now represents a quarter of our business. New technology is a very competitive field and we have had issues with industrial spies. Regrettably, we’ve found it necessary to be quite rough on occasion.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Well then, you'll be relieved to hear that I’m not remotely interested in stealing your aerospace secrets. You’re sculptures on the other hand... I haven’t seen a Praxiteles and a Lysippus in the same room since the Christie’s sale of ‘59.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ah, finally a man who has his priorities in order. So rare in this business. Tell me, what are you up to this afternoon? I’m having a little gathering at the racetrack. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, come as my guest, and we can continue our conversation about how we’re going to move your oil. EXT. RACETRACK —- SKORPIOS ENCLOSURE - DAY A Skorpios car roars past... A man clicks his stopwatch s Kuryakin, Gaby, and Uncle Rudi look on. Behind them is a throng of jet-set guests, enjoying the party, and going b and forth to the private bar.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: What’s the world coming to? A few years ago muggings never happened. I’m sorry you got hurt Comrade. Kuryakin forces a grin through gritted teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: (rubbing it in) He'll get over it, he hasn’t spent a lot of time out of Russia. Frankly, he needed toughing up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: (proudly) You were always brave. Even as a little girl. Another young woman approaches, the same one Solo saw training earlier. This is ELENA SKORPIOS. She’s very chic a muscular kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Hello Rudi.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Elena! Allow me to introduce my god- daughter Gaby. Gaby, this is Elena Skorpios, that’s her brother on the track, and also my employer.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Rudi’s told me all about you. There’s something slightly menacing about her smile. The Skorpios car is coming around.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: He drives well.  49.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Do you know much about racing? The car comes into the pits. Alexander gets out, angry. P off his helmet. Yells at his MECHANIC...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I told you to put in the bigger carburetor jets and disconnect that stupid rev limiter!

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: I did as much as I thought safe.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You have to improve the performance.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: I don’t know what else to do sir. We've tried all the other options.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Have the jets been totally cleaned and rechecked for size and flow?

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: What? Sorry, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: If I’m not mistaken, that engine’s a 1460 c.c. Coventry Climax FWB with a five bearing camshaft. It uses 40 DCOE Weber carburetors, which work predictably in cooler conditions. With this kind of road head, you have to expand the carb jetting, then you might find what you're looking for. The Mechanic calculates.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: You can’t because the expansion will produce too much fuel flow and start to foul the plugs.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: Not if you're extremely careful and tweek no more than .20 to .26mm. It's easiest to work from small to large until you get the right ratio.  50. Clearly, the Mechanic’s mind can’t keep up with the math. looks exasperated, but Alexander looks electrified.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Look lady, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Try it. The Mechanic looks lost. Gaby politely interrupts the mom

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I can do it for you if you like? She rolls up her sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo continues to play the American tourist, camera slung around his neck. He snaps pictures. Alexander, Rudi, Elen and others in the entourage. Looking slightly bored, Elena walks past him on the way t the bar. Solo considers, then decides to follow her. He passes Mr. Waverly, the distinguished English gent fro the hotel, who is sitting at a table having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo gets to the bar before Elena arrives. He leans in to BARMAN and speaks in hushed tones.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: There’s a hundred bucks in it for you if you tell her whatever she wants, I just bought the last of. Elena walks up.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Campari and soda.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: I am afraid the gentlemen has bought the last one, madam. As he mixes the drink, she looks across to Solo. He raise his eye brows.  51.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I insist you have mine.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: You don’t look like a man who drinks Campari and soda.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: It was my mother’s favorite drink.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: A mother’s boy.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Alas, which led to me being a late bloomer.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Have you caught up with the other boys?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Paddling away, but the current is strong. I’m Max Holstein with Texas Oil.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Ah, the big boys. It appears you’ve more than caught up.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I was visiting your brother and I saw you training. My history is a little rusty, but do I recall correctly that in ancient Sparta, if a man wanted to ask a woman out, he had to fight her first?

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Ohh, you are a clever boy!

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Sadly, not a tough one.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Why don’t I believe such modesty? You can always try. My office is next to my brother’s. I'll be there all tomorrow. Why don’t you drop by for a lesson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. RACETRACK - PITS — DAY Gaby, Rudi, and the mechanics watch Alexander's car going round the track. Alexander comes tearing into the pits. H jumps out of the car. He looks up at the time.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (to Gaby) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUDI
dialogues.text: Alexander, this is my goddaughter Gaby. Alexander takes Gaby’s hand, holds it a little too long.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You should come and work for me. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I live in East Germany.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Arrangements can be made... Gaby gestures to Kuryakin.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: This is my fiancee, Ilya.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. He extends his hand, but Alexander has already turned bac Gaby.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I believe that each one of us has a destiny and I can help you with yours.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You don’t know what my destiny is.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I know greatness when I see it, and I have the means to encourage its potential. I can make you great... Now show me what you did to that engine. They walk over to the car, out of Kuryakin’s earshot.  53.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You're quite full of yourself, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I can afford to be. Come to lunch tomorrow. He looks at Kuryakin with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alone. Rudi will arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kuryakin paces angrily.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: He’s a Nazi if I ever saw one.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: You need to control your temper.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I agree. Kuryakin gives him a look. SOLO (CONT’D) What do you think of him?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I think he’s an athletic, good- looking gazillionaire, who's offered me a job and made advances toward me. (beat) I think I quite like him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Yes, but do you think he’s up to no good?

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: If you mean by no good, is he planning on stealing me away from my fiancee? The answer is yes.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Well that’s not happening. No way!  54.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re upset about, you’re not even my fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: As far as he knows, I am, and I am for the purposes of this mission. So, like I said, it’s not happening. Exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I mean by “no good,” is he a neo- Nazi involved in the selling of a nuclear weapon to start a war? Not whether or not he is trying to jump your bones.

dialogues.speaker: GABY
dialogues.text: I might need a second conversation before he’ll confess to that ambition.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I agree. Go to lunch tomorrow. Alone. Rattle that tree. There’s fruit up there somewhere. We just need to find it.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: (grumpy ) I’d be better off on my own. I’m going to get an early night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo changes into some dark clothing, arms himself, and s out of his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big sign reads: TRITON SHIPPING AND AEROSPACE. Solo slips past a security guard hut and onto the pier, w appears to be entirely occupied by Skorpios. Moving through the cranes and stacks of containers, Solo looks around. There are big storage warehouses, an enormo tanker being loaded up, and at the very end, a bunker-lik building which houses Triton Aerospace.  55. This building has a high fence around it and is heavily guarded by uniformed security. Just inside is a guard tower with a spotlight, whose beam periodically rakes the front of the building. Solo is standing in the shadows, looking for the best poi of entry, when suddenly he sees another figure, also dres in black, heading towards his hiding place. Solo pulls his gun and crouches behind a crate. The figur stops exactly in the spot where Solo was concealed. Solo peeps around the edge of the crate, and sees Kuryaki also scanning the fence of the aerospace building. Kuryakin spins, wielding a vicious looking knife.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: I thought you were having an early night?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Cowboy? Dressed in black and hiding in shadows. This is what you do when the sun goes down?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: This is my patch, pal. Go and find your own warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: This is my warehouse. You’re confused again.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Look, this is my job. I don’t need you lurking about here, setting off alarms.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I don’t set off alarms, and I only work on my own. They glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You know what, this is my last mission. All I want is for it to go nice and smooth. So... you can tag along, just don’t get in the way. In and out. No one needs to know, and we can forget about it in the morning.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: You're getting out?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: None of your business. Let’s not pretend we’re pals. Shall we get on with this? He runs over to the fence. Kuryakin follows. Solo pulls out what looks like an ordinary pocket-knife, opens the scissors. Kuryakin looks dubious as Solo starts cut the wire, impressed as the blade slices through like paper. SOLO (CONT’D) Super-hardened boron sharpened with a parallax laser. Kuryakin shrugs, he pulls out what looks like a large pen

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: A parallax laser. His cutter works significantly better than Solo’s. They peel back enough of the wire to be able to slip thro Solo points to a small doorway at one end of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: The spotlight beam crosses that doorway every forty-seven seconds. There are two locks. One each? Kuryakin nods. He takes out a device that looks like a screwdriver, with a wire coming out of one end, attached an earpiece. Clearly, a super high-tech lock pick.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Go. As the spotlight passes, he sprints to the door. Solo is close behind.  57. Kuryakin sticks the earpiece in his ear, and inserts the into the bottom lock. Solo calmly takes a paperclip out of his pocket, unfolds and goes to work on the top lock. In the meantime, the spotlight has reached the end of the building, and is beginning its journey back. Solo makes short work of his lock, but Kuryakin is having trouble with his.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Struggling? Kuryakin shakes his head. The light is getting closer. SOLO (CONT’D) Need some help? Closer. SOLO (CONT’D) We don’t have all night, in fact, about ten seconds. A couple more tries with the pick, then Kuryakin gives up kicks the door, breaking the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo and Kuryakin are in a narrow corridor. They hold the breath, listening to know whether the sound of the door h alerted anyone. Apparently not.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: That was one way to do it. Kuryakin shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: We're in, aren’t we?

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: And we've left a trail. Since we have to work together, we should agree on an approach. And in my experience, ninety-nine percent of the time, the scalpel is more effective than the hammer.  58.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: I don’t need a lesson from you, Cowboy. Kuryakin is already heading down the corridor. They move past various administrative offices until they reach an open hallway with walls of glass, which look int series of laboratories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solo and Kuryakin move through the labs. They are clearly being used to manufacture high-tech electronic components rocket guidance systems and satellites, but no sign of anything to do with nuclear weaponry. Solo and Kuryakin look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: There’s nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Or there’s something we’re not seeing.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: We search and most of the time we find nothing. That is the nature of our business. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Let’s take one more pass. The sound of approaching footsteps. They duck down behind desk. A GUARD passes by, on patrol. Solo waits until he enters next room, then starts to move. Solo can see Kuryakin isn moving. SOLO (CONT’D) Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: That’s the man who stole my watch...

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: This isn’t the time... But Kuryakin is already going after him.  59. SOLO (CONT’D) This way, dammit! It’s like a game of grandmother's footsteps, with Kuryaki sneaking up behind the Guard who periodically senses something behind him, and turns, causing Kuryakin to hide Finally, Kuryakin gets within striking distance. Solo is shaking is head. Get on with it man. But Kuryakin goes in some strange stance, puts both hands behind his back, and whistles, the guard spins. Kuryakin slaps the man so hard it’s almost unbelievable. The man is paralysed, and just stands there frozen, while Kuryakin checks his wrist. Sol quite shocked by this action. SOLO (CONT’D) What have you done to him? He grabs the Guard’s left wrist.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: It’s known as the “KGB Kiss,” effective isn’t it? Took years to master, although he’s standing, he’s completely unconscious. Will be for twenty minutes, when he wakes up, he won’t remember what day it is. Solo comes in for a closer inspection of the unconscious in spite of himself, he’s fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn! It’s not my watch. He looked exactly like this man. He pushes the Guard, he collapses.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: Can we go now? Solo turns to leave, and suddenly stops. He has spotted a heavy protective suit hanging on the wall. SOLO (CONT’D) What is a radiation protection suit doing hanging in an electronics lab? He looks around the immediate area. Nothing. He then flic lone light switch on the wall, and the floor starts movin under Kuryakin’s feet.  60. Kuryakin steps to one side, as a section of floor slides to reveal a hidden staircase. Solo taps his temple with the tip of his index finger.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scalpel.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: If I hadn’t gone after my watch... But Solo is already heading down the stairs. At the botto a door that he opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lab is pretty much empty. There are a few cannisters what looks like some disassembled centrifuge equipment, b that’s it. Solo takes off his watch and presses a button. The watch emits a faint clicking sound. It is a Geiger counter. Kuryakin eyes his own wrist mournfully. The clicking gets louder as Solo approaches a large steel vault door, set into the wall. In the center is a combina lock. Kuryakin offers Solo the lock.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You sure... because if you want to try.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Hurry up. Solo goes to work on the lock. He has the finesse of an expert safecracker and makes short work of the lock. He turns the handle and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: SOLO
dialogues.text: You stick with me kid. The lead-lined vault is empty, but the Geiger counter cli madly.  61. Suddenly, there is a terrible shrieking sound. Kuryakin immediately goes into action, heading for the stairs. The floor above them is sliding shut. Kuryakin scrambles and reaches back for Solo, pulling him out just as the ga closes. Through the glass, several SECURITY GUARDS wielding machi guns can be seen approaching. Kuryakin pulls out his gun. It’s super-cool, high-tech, a huge.

dialogues.speaker: KURYAKIN
